0: Image copyright AFP Image caption The ship's cargo has been emptied, but it is feared that pollutants could spill over NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Ecuador has declared an emergency in the Galapagos Islands, saying that a cargo ship which ran aground last week still poses a threat to the archipelago's fragile ecosystem. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR The ship's cargo has been offloaded, but the authorities said pollutants, like motor oil, inside the vessel could spill and cause environmental damage. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR They were working to remove the ship. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR The Galapagos are home to unique animal species such as the giant tortoise, marine iguana and flightless cormorant. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR In 1978, the chain of volcanic islands were declared a World Heritage Site by Unesco, the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR The Ecuadorean freighter, the Galapaface I, became stranded off the rocky coast of the island of San Cristobal last Friday. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR It was carrying more than 70,000 litres (15,400 gallons) of diesel fuel. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR 'Environmental risk' NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR The governor of the Galapagos said that, despite having emptied all the fuel, some pollutants remained inside. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR "The ship is stranded and continues to present an environmental risk for the Galapagos Marine Reserve and must leave the area," Jorge Torres told the Efe news agency. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Image copyright AFP Image caption The Galapagos are home to unique animal species such as the giant tortoise NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR In a statement, the Ecuadorian government said the emergency measure would free up resources to remove the vessel. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR "As a result of the emergency declaration the Risk Management Secretariat will be able to directly carry out the purchase of goods, the procurement of services and the work that are required to overcome this emergency." NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR It did not say how long it would take to complete the removal of the vessel. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Darwin's finches NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR This is not the first ship accident in the Galapagos. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR In 2001, an oil tanker also became stranded off the coast of San Cristobal, spilling fuel and decimating the marine iguana population.
